It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text. For all other use contact the Tennessee State Library and Archives, 403 Seventh Avenue North, Nashville, TN 37243-0312. (615) 741-2764.

bibl.title: [Letter] 1817 Nov. 18 [to] James Winchester / Jno. Navarre
bibl.author: Navarre, Jno.
bibl.note: This is a letter from Jno. Navarre to James Winchester dated November 18, 1817, explaining the death of Mrs. Navarre and the return of some of Winchester's personal belongings.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

opener.salute:
Genrl General . Winchester
Dr Dear Sir . Sir

div.p:
having a long time wished to hear from you but not being gratified, I now have to inform you, that mrs misses . Navarre pased passed on the 22n day of Janey January . 1870 your watch, specticls spectacles , & penknife that is to say I think thay they belonged to you, She picked them up on the hastened morning of the destruction of your property and mine, and put them in her breasts; the watch I put into the hands of Col Colonel . Butler, of Kentucky to deliver it to you, which I hope you have recieved received , I now forward the specticles spectacles & penknife, with Col Colonel . Bathers recept receipt for the watch by my friend Col. John Anderson whom takes on my claim on government for my losses, and hope you will assist him by your certificat certificate that you had a Military deposit in my house
house; & will not undertake to give you a detail of my sufferance after that fatal morning untill until the return of the American troops to this Country but my frind friend if he has the Honor of Seeing you will give it in fall.
div.closer:
hopping hoping you enjoy good health I have the honor to be your most obedt obedient & Humble Servnt Servant
Jno John Navarre
Genrl General . James Winchester Tennessee
H Handed . by Col. John Anderson
